titleInfo.title: Young Dead
titleInfo.subTitle: A Multimethod Study of the Influence of Digital Media Convergence on the Creation and Sustainability of an Online Community

mods:mods.abstract: Since their formation in 1965, the Grateful Dead have consistently captivated audiences, both young and old, on such a large scale that the Dead fanbase have their own, unique label and subculture. Though scholarship on the Dead and the Deadhead community has always existed, The Young Dead deserve attention. The Young Dead are Deadheads that were born post-1995 who, despite not being able to see the band perform live, still identify as significant members of the Grateful Dead fandom community. Moreover, not only have fans of the Grateful Dead persevered throughout the band's existence, but even after the death of Garcia in 1995 (the assumed "end" of the band) the persistence of Deadhead fans, and their culture, within society, literature, and scholarship shows a possible connection to digital media convergence and digital spaces. Thus, The Young Dead allow us to see not only the persistence of a culture and phenomenon over more than half a century, but a recreation, reiteration, and reformation of the Deadhead fan base itself that seems to be directly related to technology and digital spaces/environments. In order to understand how The Young Dead community is composing and communicating within convergent online spaces to form significant bonds, I outlined four research questions: (1) How do The Young Dead interact in convergence spaces? (2) How do The Young Dead describe themselves? (3) How do The Young Dead describe their fandom? (4) How does the fandom function as a community within these spaces? To answer these questions, I used a multimethod methodology and collected qualitative and quantitative data through surveys and interviews. In order to analyze the data, I used an inductive coding scheme based on the data I collected. Through the survey and interview method, I was able to gain a deeper understanding of The Young Dead community and shed light on the communicative and compositional practices that they are employing within convergent online spaces. These findings provide insight into online fan communities that have possible implications in rhetorical and compositional pedagogical practice, digital archive work, and fandom studies.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
Convergent Spaces, Deadhead, Digital Archives, Media Convergence, Online Communites, Online Fandom
Michael Neal, Professor Directing Thesis; Leigh Edwards, Committee Member; Gary Burnett, Committee Member; Jaclyn Fiscus-Cannaday, Committee Member.
